comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Given the fact that the street had been wrecked between 1916 and 1922 it is very difficult to place the shot.  I think that you are probably correct and that the old Georgian houses you can see the backs of are those on Parnell St.  A Thoms directory of that era might give you a better fix?

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: Well... the Sinn Fein Rebellion Handbook published a list of damaged or destroyed buildings and included "Henry Taaffe - Gentlemen's Outfitter" at 8 Upper Sackville Street. And if you look at the large version of this pic, you can see "Taaffe" and "Outfitter" on the signs beside the Findlater building... But I can't make sense of the actual landscape on Google Streetview. The Irish Times archive has the headline "Republican meeting in Sackville St" for 18 August, and "Republicans in Dublin" for 20 August, but I can't access the actual articles.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65361386@N05] We have access to the Irish Times and Irish Indo in the Library so I'll try to check those over the next couple of days...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39761459@N00
comment._content: This is indeed O'Connell Street - we are looking at the old Findlaters on the corner with Cathal Burgha street. The building at the extreme left with the arches at first floor level was included in the subsequent rebuilding and survived until the 1970s when the whole lot was replaced with an office block. See Lost Dublin, by Frederick O'Dwyer, 1982

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39761459@N00] Thank you. Will seek out Lost Dublin, and your comment reminded me to carry through on promise to check Irish Times/Indo for articles mentioned by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65361386@N05] above. Mea culpa.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: À propos of this post here's the streetview of this location

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Found a report of this meeting in the Irish Independent on Monday, 20 August 1923. It was a "large Anti-Treaty meeting in O'Connell St., Dublin" and featured the young sons of Éamon de Valera and Erskine Childers. Our options for the woman on the podium are Dr. Kathleen Lynn (1874-1955) or Countess Markievicz (1868-1927). Both are reported as speaking...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Perfect!

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I think the speaker might be Kathleen Lynn and that the woman seated on the left hand side of the podium might be the Countess

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content:
As an aside, this from James Joyce's Ulysses ( Episode 17 Ithaca )
What additional attractions might the grounds contain? As addenda, a tennis and fives court, a shrubbery, a glass summerhouse with tropical palms, equipped in the best botanical manner a rockery with waterspray, a beehive arranged on humane principles, oval flowerbeds in rectangular grassplots set with eccentric ellipses of scarlet and chrome tulips, blue scillas, crocuses, polyanthus, sweet William, sweat pea, lily of the valley (bulbs obtainable from sir James W. Mackey (Limited) (wholesale and retail) seed and bulb merchant and nurseryman, agent for chemical manures, 23 Sackville street, upper), an orchard, kitchen garden and vinery, protected against illegal trespassers by glasstopped mural enclosures, a lumbershed with padlock for various inventoried implements.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Lovely aside!  :)

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Joyce was right, you really can reconstruct the city from his novel! :-)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03/] No, the lady on the left of the podium is an elderly woman, the countess was younger and tended to dress in a more fashionable manner than that.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] By 1923 the countess would have been 55 and she died four years later. c.f. this photo taken in 1916 It's the pronounced cheekbones on the photo above that suggests it might be her. The woman standing at the edge of the podium doesn't have the Countess' broad shoulders which makes me suspect it is Dr Lynn.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] I can see what you mean but she was gaunt and in failing health at that time whereas that lady looks settled and a little plump, or do my eyes deceive me?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] You may be right - I'm more certain of Dr Lynn - I think I detect a hint of spectacles in the photograph.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Having had another good look at it in the largest format I can manage I do agree.  That lady is definitely not the Countess, is wearing glasses and the resemblance to the photos of Dr. Lynn are very strong.  Well done.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Well done to both of you, thanks!
